meta.description:
Reference Label Generation Rules for the Ethiopic Script

Overview

This document specifies a reference set of Label Generation Rules for the Ethiopic script for the second level. The starting point for the development of this LGR can be found in the related Root Zone LGR [RZ-LGR-4-Ethi]. For details and additional background on the script, see "Proposal for Ethiopic Script Root Zone LGR [Proposal-Ethiopic]". The format of this file follows [RFC 7940].

Repertoire

The repertoire contains 311 code points for letters and only includes code points used by languages that are actively written in the Ethiopic script. The repertoire is a subset of [Unicode 6.3]. For details, see Section 5, "Repertoire" in [Proposal-Ethiopic]. (The proposal cited has been adopted for the Ethiopic script portion of the Root Zone LGR.)

For the second level, the repertoire has been augmented with the ASCII digits, U+0030 to U+0039 and U+002D HYPHEN-MINUS, for a total of 322 repertoire elements.

Each code point or range is tagged with the script or scripts that the code point is used with, and one or more references documenting sufficient justification for inclusion in the repertoire, see "References" below. Comments identify the languages using the code point.

Variants

This reference LGR is designed for use in zones shared by more than one script. Where appropriate, cross-script variants have been defined to mutually exclude labels from different scripts that could otherwise be substituted by the users. Once a label has been delegated for one script, any variant labels from other scripts consisting of cross-script variants would be blocked. Any label containing at least one code point that is not a cross-script variant would be considered distinct. Because of that, even large numbers of defined cross-script variants generally do not lead to a high percentage of labels experiencing a collision.

According to Section 6, "Variants" in [Proposal-Ethiopic], there are significant numbers of code points that can be used interchangeably in the writing system of the Amharic language. Two code points are variants of each other if they can be used interchangeably in the writing system of the Amharic language and their use yields identical lexical terms for canonical labels (for labels with dictionary meaning) and same or identical representation(s) for non-canonical labels (for labels that do not have dictionary meaning). The Amharic language is the official working language of the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia and many of the states within the federal system. Due to security problems these variants pose, they are treated as script wide variants beyond the Amharic language.

Variant Disposition: All variants are of type "blocked", making labels that differ only by these variants mutually exclusive: whichever label containing either of these variants is chosen earlier would be delegated, while any other equivalent label should be blocked.

This LGR does not define allocatable variants.

The specification of variants in this reference LGR follows the guidelines in [RFC 8228].

Character Classes

This LGR does not define character classes.

Whole Label Evaluation (WLE) and Context Rules

Common Rules

  • Hyphen Restrictions — restrictions on the allowable placement of hyphens (no leading/ending hyphen and no hyphen in positions 3 and 4). These restrictions are described in section 4.2.3.1 of RFC 5891 [150]. They are implemented here as context rule on U+002D (-) HYPHEN-MINUS.
  • Leading Combining Marks — restrictions on the allowable placement of combining marks (no leading combining mark). This rule is described in section 4.2.3.2 of RFC 5891 [150].

Default Actions

Actions include the default actions for LGRs as well as that needed to invalidate labels with misplaced combining marks. They are marked with ⍟. For a description see [RFC 7940].

Ethiopic-specific Rules

According to Section 7, "Whole Label Evaluation (WLE) Rules" in [Proposal-Ethiopic], this LGR does not define rules specific to Ethiopic.

Methodology and Contributors

This reference LGR for Ethiopic for the 2nd Level has been developed by Michel Suignard and Asmus Freytag, based on the Root Zone LGR for Ethiopic and information contained or referenced therein, see [RZ-LGR-4-Ethi]. Suitable extensions for the second level have been applied according to the [Guidelines]. The original proposal for a Root Zone LGR for the Ethiopic script, that this reference LGR is based on, was developed by the Ethiopic Generation Panel. For more information on methodology and contributors to the underlying Root Zone LGR, see Sections 4 and 8 in [Proposal-Ethiopic], as well as [RZ-LGR-Overview].

References

The following general references are cited in this document:

[Guidelines]
ICANN, "Guidelines for Developing Reference LGRs for the Second Level, (Los Angeles, California: ICANN, 27 May 2020), https://www.icann.org/en/system/files/files/lgr-guidelines-second-level-06jan16-en.pdf
[Proposal-Ethiopic]
Ethiopic Generation Panel, "Proposal for Ethiopic Script Root Zone LGR", 17 May, 2017, https://www.icann.org/en/system/files/files/proposal-ethiopic-lgr-17may17-en.pdf
[RFC 7940]
Davies, K. and A. Freytag, "Representing Label Generation Rulesets Using XML", RFC 7940, August 2016, http://www.rfc-editor.org/info/rfc7940
[RFC 8228]
A. Freytag, "Guidance on Designing Label Generation Rulesets (LGRs) Supporting Variant Labels", RFC 8228, August 2017, https://www.rfc-editor.org/info/rfc8228
[RZ-LGR-Overview]
Integration Panel, "Root Zone Label Generation Rules - LGR-4: Overview and Summary", 5 November 2020 (PDF), https://www.icann.org/sites/default/files/lgr/lgr-4-overview-05nov20-en.pdf
[RZ-LGR-4-Ethi]
ICANN, Root Zone Label Generation Rules for the Ethiopic Script (und-Ethi) , 5 November 2020 (XML) https://www.icann.org/sites/default/files/lgr/lgr-4-ethiopic-script-05nov20-en.xml
[Unicode 6.3]
The Unicode Consortium. The Unicode Standard, Version 6.3.0, (Mountain View, CA: The Unicode Consortium, 2013. ISBN 978--936213-08-5) http://www.unicode.org/versions/Unicode6.3.0/

For references consulted particularly in designing the repertoire for the Ethiopic script for the second level. please see details in the Table of References below. Reference [3] and [7] refer to the Unicode Standard versions in which corresponding code points were initially encoded. Reference [101] to [104] correspond to sources given in [Proposal-Ethiopic] for justifying the inclusion of for the corresponding code points. Entries in the table may have multiple source reference values. Reference [150] indicates the source for common rules.

reference.comment: Any code point originally encoded in Unicode 1.1
Any code point originally encoded in Unicode 3.0
Any code point originally encoded in Unicode 4.1
Ethiopic Script Versions for the Eight Languages

references.reference: The Online Encyclopedia of Writing Systems & Languages, https://www.omniglot.com/writing/amharic.htm, https://www.omniglot.com/writing/argobba.htm, https://www.omniglot.com/writing/awngi.htm, https://www.omniglot.com/writing/harari.htm, https://www.omniglot.com/writing/xamtanga.htm, https://www.omniglot.com/writing/silte.htm, https://www.omniglot.com/writing/tigre.htm, https://www.omniglot.com/writing/tigrinya.htm

reference.comment: Cited as Auxiliary Evidence for Tigrigna Code Points

references.reference: Corpus Analysis performed by crawling 598 html and 40 PDF files with Tigrigna Contents published online, August 2016

reference.comment: Cited as Auxiliary Evidence for Amharic Code Points

references.reference: Corpus Analysis performed by crawling 14,850 html Amharic Contents of size .8 GB published online, August 2016

reference.comment: Cited for Amharic-Driven Variants in Ethiopic Script

references.reference: Daniel Yacob “ Application of the Double Metaphone Algorithm to Amharic Orthography”, International Conference of Ethiopian Studies XV, https://www.semanticscholar.org/paper/Application-of-the-Double-Metaphone-Algorithm-to-Yacob/2f71033d74d2f17a9502867e4a43dc4374500726
RFC 5891, Internationalized Domain Names in Applications (IDNA): Protocol http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5891

rule.name: leading-combining-mark
rule.comment: RFC 5891 restrictions on placement of combining marks ⍟

rule.name: hyphen-minus-disallowed
rule.comment: RFC 5891 restrictions on placement of U+002D ⍟
no consecutive hyphens in third and fourth position in the label

action.comment: labels with leading combining marks are invalid ⍟
any variant label with a code point out of repertoire is invalid ⍟
any variant label containing blocked variants is blocked ⍟
variant labels with all variants allocatable are allocatable ⍟
